Research article Mechanistic insights into the formation pathway of acetone in selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2 over Au/uncalcined TS-1 catalyst Zhihua Zhang Writing – review & editing Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Wenyao Chen Writing – review & editing Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Yueqiang Cao Writing – review & editing Validation Investigation Formal analysis Jinwei Sun Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation Yuxia Zhong Validation Methodology Investigation Shudong Shi Validation Investigation Formal analysis Xuezhi Duan Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Xinggui Zhou Supervision Project administration Funding acquisition ⁎ State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China State Key Laboratory of Chemical Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology, Shanghai 200237, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Understanding the reaction mechanism is crucial for the rational design of highly efficient catalysts. Herein, we report new insights into the formation pathway of acetone in the selective oxidation of propane using H2 and O2 catalyzed by uncalcined titanium silicalite-1 (i.e., TS-1-B) immobilized Au nanoparticles, based on kinetic analysis, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy, and well-designed discrimination experiments. Increasing the concentrations of propane and H2 favored the formation of both acetone and isopropanol. However, a higher O2 concentration decreased the net rate of isopropanol formation while increasing that of acetone formation. The acetone formation rate increased with the concentration of co-fed isopropanol. Moreover, the results of co-feeding isopropanol with different reactants demonstrated that isopropanol can be converted to acetone by oxygen at the interface between Au nanoparticles and supports with a conversion near 100%. Moreover, we also found that the Au-Ti proximity sites contribute more significantly to the formation of acetone compared to the remote Ti sites in the Au/TS-1-B catalyst. Based on the above results, we propose that acetone primarily originates from the oxidation of isopropanol by oxygen at the Au-Ti interface of Au-Ti bifunctional catalysts, which differs from the claim in previous reports that acetone is formed through the oxidation of isopropoxy intermediate species by hydro-peroxy species on the Ti sites. Moreover, isopropanol and acetone undergo deep oxidation to form CO2 and ethanol as by-products. Keywords Selective oxidation Propane Gold catalysts Titanium silicalite-1 Formation pathway Active sites Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Acetone (Ac) is an important chemical feedstock widely used in the synthesis of high value-added chemicals such as bisphenol A, methyl methacrylate (MMA), and isopropanol (IPA) [1–3]. Nowadays, acetone is mainly produced as a co-product in the synthesis of phenol through the cumene process, using propene and benzene as raw materials [1,4]. Developing new process for directly producing phenol from benzene has been put on the agenda, alternative synthesis routes for acetone are needed [1]. Oyama et al. reported that propane can be selectively oxidized to acetone using H2 and O2 over a catalyst of Au nanoparticles (NPs) supported on titanium silicalite-1 (TS-1) [1,2]. This method is simple, cost-effective, environmentally friendly, and sustainable [1–3]. Those authors proposed that the Au/TS-1 catalyst operates through a bifunctional mechanism: H2 and O2 first react on the surface of Au NPs to form hydro-peroxy species, which then migrate to the Ti4+ sites and form Ti-OOH reaction intermediates. Subsequently, propane reacts with Ti-OOH to produce IPA and acetone [2]. Our own recent work demonstrated that Au NPs immobilized on the external surface of uncalcined TS-1 (TS-1-B), where the micropores are blocked by the TPA+ templates, can also selectively oxidize propane to acetone with H2 and O2 [3]. The as-prepared 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst shows a stable acetone formation rate of ca. 97 gAc·h−1·kgcat –1 and an acetone selectivity of ca. 87 %, outperforming the previously reported 0.5 wt% Au/TS-1 catalyst (82 gAc·h−1·kgcat –1 and 85 %, respectively). In addition, adding trace amounts of Pd (Au/Pd molar ratio = 20) to 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B significantly enhanced the acetone formation rate to ca. 170 gAc·h−1·kgcat –1, and no obvious deactivation was observed over 130 h, much better than the reported 0.5 wt% Au/TS-1 catalyst [2,3]. It was also found that the narrow micropores of Au/TS-1 catalyst can be easily blocked by coke deposits during the reaction [5], and the tiny Au clusters located in the micropores are prone to agglomeration [6,7]. In contrast, Au/TS-1-B showed excellent stability, with no significant agglomeration of the Au NPs over 100 h [8]. The advantages of the Au/TS-1-B catalysts mentioned above would be beneficial for gaining more insight into the reaction mechanisms of selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2. Previously reported work proposed that acetone is formed through an i-propoxy intermediate species, which are formed by the reaction between propane and Ti-OOH reaction intermediates [1,2]. The i-propoxy intermediate species formed on the Ti sites further react with the hydro-peroxy species to form acetone [1,2]. Moreover, the i-propoxy intermediate species can also be transformed into isopropanol [1,2]. Therefore, acetone and IPA are formed in parallel reactions. Notably, some previous studies demonstrated that supported Pd catalysts and metal oxides (e.g., NiO and PtO) can oxidize isopropanol to acetone by oxygen molecules [9–11]. Given the ability of Au NPs in Au/TS-1-B to absorb and activate O2 [2,12,13] and the significantly lower concentration of hydro-peroxy species compared to oxygen on the catalyst surface, it is reasonable to assume that acetone is more readily formed through the oxidation of isopropanol by O2 adsorbed on the surface of Au NPs. However, no relevant studies have been published to date. For the rational design of highly efficient Au-Ti bifunctional catalysts for the selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2, a deeper understanding is needed for the acetone formation mechanism over the Au/TS-1-B catalyst. In addition, understanding the formation mechanisms of by-products is also key to improving the selectivity of acetone over the Au/TS-1-B catalyst. However, to date, no literature reports have been found on the formation pathways of by-products (such as CO2 and ethanal) over Au-Ti bifunctional catalysts in the selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2. According to previously reported work, two different types of Ti sites have been identified on Au/TS-1 catalysts: those adjacent to the Au NPs (i.e., Au-Ti proximity sites) and those far away from the Au NPs (i.e., remote Ti sites) [12,13]. Our previous work has demonstrated that, compared with the Au-Ti proximity sites, the remote Ti sites in Au/TS-1-B contribute more significantly to the direct gas-phase epoxidation of propene with H2 and O2 to produce propene oxide (PO) [13]. However, the influence of different Ti sites on acetone formation remains unclear, which is also crucial for the rational design of highly efficient Au-Ti bifunctional catalysts for the reaction. We have also reported that, compared to the Au/TS-1-B catalyst, the tandem catalyst formed by physically mixing Au/uncalcined S-1 (i.e., S-1-B) catalyst and TS-1-B particles has fewer Au-Ti proximity sites [13–15]. Therefore, it is possible to determine the contribution of different Ti sites to acetone formation by comparing the Au/TS-1-B catalyst and the Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst. In this work, we propose a new insight into the formation pathway of acetone in selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2 over Au/TS-1-B catalyst by combining kinetics analysis, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), and well-designed discrimination experiments. The acetone formation rate over the Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst was much lower than those over the Au/TS-1-B and Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalysts, indicating that Au-Ti proximity sites are the main active sites for acetone formation. Moreover, it was observed that the acetone formation rate over the Au/TS-1-B catalyst gradually increased during the induction period, while the isopropanol formation rate remained almost unchanged. Additionally, the selectivity for isopropanol gradually increased with rising space velocity. These results suggest that isopropanol may serve as a reaction intermediate for the reaction. The effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of the Au/TS-1-B catalyst was also investigated. The selectivity for isopropanol decreased with increasing reaction temperature, unlike by-products such as CO2 and ethanal. This indicates that the reaction producing isopropanol is less temperature-sensitive than those for by-products. In addition, the formation rates of acetone and isopropanol increased with increasing concentrations of hydrogen and propane, but increasing the oxygen concentration enhanced the acetone formation rate while reducing the isopropanol formation rate. To explore these differences, in situ DRIFTS was used to analyze the adsorption behavior of propane, acetone, and isopropanol. It was found that acetone adsorbs much more strongly on Ti sites than on Si sites, unlike isopropanol. Therefore, the acetone formation rate decreased with increasing concentration of co-fed acetone, indicating a significant inhibitory effect. However, the acetone formation rate increased with increasing concentration of co-fed isopropanol, suggesting that isopropanol may be converted to acetone under reaction conditions. To verify this hypothesis and gain deeper insights into acetone formation pathways, discrimination experiments were conducted by co-feeding isopropanol under various atmospheres (O2, O2 + H2, etc.) over different catalysts. The results indicate that acetone primarily originates from the oxidation of isopropanol by O2 at the interface between the Au NPs and TS-1-B or S-1-B particles, differing from the previously proposed mechanism involving the oxidation of i-propoxy intermediate species by hydro-peroxy species on Ti sites. Furthermore, by comparing the products generated from co-feeding isopropanol and acetone on different catalysts, it was found that acetaldehyde and CO2 mainly result from the deep oxidation of isopropanol and acetone. The findings reported in this work reveal that increasing the number of Au-Ti proximity sites and enhancing the desorption of acetone from the catalyst surface should be prioritized in the synthesis of highly efficient Au-Ti bifunctional catalysts for this reaction in the future. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst synthesis TS-1-B with a Si/Ti molar ratio of 100 was synthesized according to our previously established method [16]. In a typical process, 2.00 g of polyoxyethylene 20-sorbitan monolaurate (Tween-20) and 30.00 g of H2O (18.2 MΩ cm−1) were added to a polypropylene plastic cup (ca. 350 mL), followed by the addition of a polytetrafluoroethylene magnetic stir bar (diameter ca. 14 mm, length ca. 39 mm). The cup was placed in a water bath at 35 °C and magnetically stirred vigorously. Considering the temperature difference between the water bath and the solution in the polypropylene plastic cup, before synthesis of TS-1-B, the temperature of water bath was determined to match the required synthesis temperature, as measured by an alcohol thermometer placed in the middle of the solution. After stirring the mixture of Tween-20 and H2O for 1 h, 26.36 g of tetrapropylammonium hydroxide (TPAOH, 25 wt%) was added into the above mixture and stirred for another 1 h at 35 °C. Subsequently, 37.50 g of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS, 99.8 % purity) was added dropwise using a syringe pump (80 mL/h), and the mixture was stirred for 1 h at 35 °C to promote the hydrolysis of TEOS. Concurrently, a mixture of 0.31 g of titanium butoxide (TBOT, 99.99 % purity) and 11.69 g of isopropanol (99.5 % purity) was magnetically stirred for 45 min. This mixture was then added dropwise (9 mL/h) to the first mixture containing hydrolyzed TEOS via a syringe pump while stirring. After stirring at room temperature for 1 h, the resulting gel was heated to 80 °C and kept for 5 h to remove alcohol. Concurrently, 50 mL of H2O was added dropwise via a syringe pump, and this procedure was repeated four times at different addition rates (80, 50, 30, and 30 mL/h). Subsequently, the gel was evenly distributed into two Teflon-lined stainless-steel autoclaves (100 mL) and then crystallized at 165 °C for 24 h. The resulting slurry was centrifuged (8500 rpm, 15 min), washed by suspending the solid in 50 mL of H2O and stirring for 2 min, centrifuged again (8500 rpm, 10 min), and dried at 70 °C for 6 h in a convection oven to obtain TS-1-B. S-1-B was prepared using the same procedure except for the addition of TBOT. The Au/TS-1-B catalyst was prepared by the DPU method according to the literature [8,17–19]. Typically, 1.05 mL of HAuCl4 solution (0.96 gAu/L) and 39.0 mL of H2O were first mixed in a quartz cup, followed by addition of 0.09 g of urea. After magnetic stirring for 2 min at room temperature, 1.00 g of TS-1-B sample was added to the above solution and stirred for another 2 min at room temperature. Afterward, the quartz cup was covered with plastic wrap, placed in a water bath, and the entire water bath was kept in the dark by covering it with aluminum foil. Under continuous magnetic stirring, the slurry was heated to 90 °C at a rate of ∼ 2 °C/min and then aged for 6 h. The resulting slurry was centrifuged (6500 rpm) for 6 min, washed once with 40 mL of H2O, and centrifuged again. Finally, the obtained solid was placed into a vacuum chamber, which was then connected to a vacuum pump via hoses for continuous vacuum drying (vacuum pressure of ca. −0.1 MPa) overnight at room temperature. The Au/S-1-B catalyst was synthesized using the same procedure, except using S-1-B instead of TS-1-B. The Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst was synthesized by physically mixing TS-1-B sample and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst (0.075 g each). The 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalyst was prepared by physically mixing 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst with S-1-B sample (0.075 g each). Considering the temperature difference between the water bath and the solution in the quartz cup, a pilot experiment was conducted to determine the set temperature of water bath that ensures the solution in the quartz cup reaches the target temperature (90 °C). The procedure was identical to that used for the Au/TS-1-B catalyst, except that only 40 mL of water was added to the quartz cup, and an alcohol thermometer was placed in the middle. Once the thermometer indicated that the water in the cup had reached 90 °C and remained stable for 2 h, the set temperature of the water bath was confirmed to meet the requirements for the synthesis of both Au/TS-1-B and Au/S-1-B catalysts. 2.2 Characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD; Rigaku D/Max2550VB/PC, Cu Kα radiation) analysis was used to identify the crystal phases of Au/TS-1-B and Au/S-1-B catalysts. Ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis, PerkinElmer Lambda 35) spectroscopy analysis was used to probe the coordination state of Au/TS-1-B, using BaSO4 as a reference. The N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of Au/TS-1-B and Au/S-1-B were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The pressure range used to calculate the specific surface area of different samples was P/P0 = 0.01–0.3. Inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES; Agilent ICP-OES 720) was used to determine Au loading in Au/TS-1-B and Au/S-1-B, after digesting the samples using a mixture of 15 mL aqua regia and 15 mL HF. High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) was employed to analyze the Au particle size distribution in Au/TS-1-B and Au/S-1-B, using a Tecnai G2 F20 S-TWIN instrument equipped with a digitally processed STEM imaging system. To prepare the HAADF-STEM sample, 10 mg of catalyst was placed in a 2 mL centrifuge tube, added with 1 mL of anhydrous ethanol, and ultrasonicated at 37 Hz for 10 min at room temperature. Afterwards, 50 μL of the upper suspension was dropped onto a carbon film copper grid, and HAADF-STEM observation was conducted after the ethanol had completely evaporated. The size distributions of Au NPs in different catalysts were determined by counting approximately 150 random NPs. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS; Kratos Axis XSAM-800 with an Al Kα X-ray anode) was used to characterize the electronic structures of Au/TS-1-B and Au/S-1-B. The binding energies of Au/TS-1-B and Au/S-1-B catalysts were calibrated based on the C 1 s peak located at 284.8 eV. In-situ DRIFTS was used to analyze the adsorption behavior of reactants and products on the surfaces of TS-1-B, S-1-B, Au/TS-1-B, and Au/S-1-B. The experiments were performed on a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 spectrometer outfitted with a liquid nitrogen-cooled mercury cadmium telluride detector. The cuboid cell was a Harrick cell with a Praying Mantis diffuse reflection accessory. The resolution was set to 2 cm–1. Details of the in-situ DRIFTS are provided in Supporting Information . 2.3 Catalytic tests and kinetic experiments Selective oxidation of propane using H2 and O2 was performed in a tubular quartz reactor (i.d., 6 mm). A thermowell equipped with a thermocouple was used to measure the reactor temperature. The thermowell was first inserted from the bottom up into the quartz tube reactor, which was positioned approximately in the middle of the reactor. Subsequently, a certain amount of quartz wool was placed on top of the thermowell, followed by placing the catalyst (0.15 g, 100 mesh) on the quartz wool. Then, the reactor was heated from room temperature to 300 °C with a ramp rate of 1.67 °C/min in a H2 /N2 (36 vol% H2 in N2, 50 mL/min) gas mixture, and then reduced at 300 °C for 2 h. Subsequently, the reactor was cooled down to 200 °C within 70 min. Au/TS-1-B, Au/S-1-B, Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B and Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalysts were tested in the catalytic reaction using the same procedure, all at 200 °C with a feed gas containing 10/10/10/70 vol% of C3H8/H2/O2/N2 (35 mL/min, space velocity = 14000 mL·h–1·kgcat –1). The reactants and products were analyzed using an online gas chromatograph (GC) equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (for TDX-1 packed column) and a flame ionization detector (for DB-FFAP capillary column). The TDX-1 packed column (3 mm × 2 m) was used to detect H2, O2, and CO2, while the DB-FFAP capillary column (0.32 mm × 60 m) was used to detect propane, ethanal, acrolein, acetone, isopropanol, and propanal. The propane conversion, product selectivity, acetone formation rate, and carbon balance were calculated as previously reported [2,3], and the details are described in Supporting Information . The acetone formation rates over the two tandem catalysts of 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B were calculated based on the mass of TS-1-B (0.075 g). The estimated Mears criterion for both heat and external mass transfer limitations in this study was much smaller than 0.15, confirming the absence of heat transfer and external mass transfer limitations (for details see Supporting Information ) [20]. Additionally, because the estimated Thiele modulus was less than 1, the internal mass transfer limitations can also be neglected (for details see Supporting Information ) [20]. To investigate the effect of reaction temperature on the catalytic performance of 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst, the catalyst was first reacted at 200 °C for 30 h to reach a stable state and then tested at different temperatures. Three repeated GC sampling injections were conducted at Three repeated GC sampling injections were conducted at each reaction temperature, with a 1-hour interval between each injection, and the reported data reflects the mean of the three injections. The kinetic experiments were conducted by independently varying the concentration of one reactant in the feed gas (propane, H2, or O2) from 4 to 20 vol%, while adjusting the N2 balance to maintain a total flow rate of 35 mL/min. The experimental details are provided in Supporting Information . To investigate the acetone formation pathways, discrimination experiments were performed by introducing different reaction atmospheres (shown in Table 1 ) into various catalytic materials, including the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts as well as TS-1-B and S-1-B samples. TS-1-B and S-1-B samples were reduced by the same procedure used for the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst. The experimental details are provided in Supporting Information . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Primary active sites in Au/TS-1-B catalyst Recently, our group demonstrated that remote Ti sites in the Au/TS-1-B catalyst, which are far from the Au NPs, make a greater contribution than the Au-Ti proximity sites to the direct gas-phase epoxidation of propene to PO using H2 and O2 [13]. The HOOH species generated on the Au NPs can also diffuse to the remote Ti active sites for propene epoxidation; that is, PO is formed on remote Ti sites through a tandem mechanism. However, it remains unclear which type of Ti sites on Au/TS-1-B is more active in the selective oxidation of propane to acetone using H2 and O2. This is important for understanding the reaction mechanism and for the rational design of highly active Au/TS-1-B catalysts for the reaction. To distinguish the contributions of Au-Ti proximity sites and remote Ti sites in the selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2 over the Au/TS-1-B catalyst, a tandem catalyst with separated Au and Ti sites was designed. This tandem catalyst was prepared by physically mixing 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst and TS-1-B sample, which has fewer Au-Ti proximity sites (as displayed in Fig. 1 b) [13]. Subsequently, we compared the properties and catalytic performance of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B, 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B, and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts. First, ICP measurements of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts confirm that both have an Au loading of near 0.10 wt% ( Table S1 ). Their XRD patterns (shown in Fig. S1 ) both show four diffraction peaks located at 2θ = 7.9°, 8.8°, 23.1°, along with a single peak appearing at 24.4°, indicating the presence of typical MFI topological structure with orthorhombic symmetry [5,21,22]. The UV–vis spectrum of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst ( Fig. S2 ) shows an absorption peak at ca. 220 nm attributed to isolated tetrahedrally coordinated titanium species [19,23–25], and there is no absorption peak attributed to octahedrally coordinated titanium species in the range of 250–280 nm. Additionally, no characteristic peak of anatase TiO2 at around 330 nm is observed [5,26], indicating that most of Ti in the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst is isolated tetrahedrally coordinated titanium species. Fig. S3 displays the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts. For both catalysts, the adsorption capacity at P/P0 < 0.02 is minimal, indicating that they contain negligible micropores [8,19], which is consistent with their nearly zero micropore volumes ( Table S2 ). These results confirm that the micropores in these catalysts are blocked by the TPA+ templates [5,8]. The HAADF-STEM images of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts (shown in Fig. 1 c and e) show that the Au NPs are uniformly dispersed on the surfaces of TS-1-B and S-1-B, respectively. The average Au particle size in the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst (shown in Fig. 1 d) is approximately 2.1 nm, which is. similar to that of the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst (ca. 2.3 nm, shown in Fig. 1 f). The Au 4f spectra of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts are shown in Fig. 1 g. As shown, both catalysts exhibit the Au0 4f7/2 peak, indicating the presence of Au0 [19,27,28]. The 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst shows a relatively higher binding energy than the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst (ca. 83.73 vs. 83.63 eV), which may be attributed to the smaller Au NPs in the former [29]. Fig. S4 displays the Ti 2p XPS spectrum of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst. The Ti 2p3/2 peak observed at 459.84 eV is usually attributed to Ti4+ species, while the minor peak at 457.93 eV can be attributed to Ti3+ species [8,19]. The catalytic performances of different catalysts are illustrated in Fig. 1 h. To ensure a fair comparison, we also evaluated the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalyst, which was prepared by physically mixing 0.075 g of 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst and 0.075 g of S-1-B sample. The variations in the formation rate and selectivity of acetone over these catalysts as a function of time are shown in Fig. S5 , while the corresponding values for the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst are depicted in Fig. 2 . As shown in Fig. 1 h, the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst exhibits lower acetone formation rate (ca 38 gAc·h−1·kgcat –1) and selectivity (ca. 77.2 %) compared to the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B (ca. 135 gAc·h−1·kgcat –1 and 85.3 %, respectively) and 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B (ca. 100 gAc·h−1·kgcat –1 and 86.4 %, respectively) catalysts. Therefore, based on the above results as well as the factor that the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst has less Au-Ti proximity sites compared to the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalysts, we can reasonably assume that the Au-Ti proximity sites in Au/TS-1-B catalyst contribute more significantly to acetone formation. The 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst displays a much higher acetone formation rate, nearly two orders of magnitude greater than that of the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst (shown in Fig. S6 ). This result shows that the Au NPs alone cannot effectively catalyze the selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2, highlighting the importance of synergy between Au and Ti sites in this reaction. Additionally, the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst also shows higher selectivity for acetone (ca. 85.3 %), while the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst produces more by-products with a lower acetone selectivity of approximately 75.2 % (shown in Fig. S6 ). 3.2 Kinetic behavior of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B in the reaction Fig. 2 a shows the acetone (Ac) formation rate and propane conversion over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst at different times-on-stream. It is evident that the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst exhibits an induction period. Our previous work demonstrated that partial Ti active sites in the Au/TS-1-B catalyst are covered by the TPA+ templates adsorbed on the external surface of TS-1-B [19,27]. The external surface area gradually increased during the induction period (shown in Table S3 ). This is mainly because the strongly oxidizing HOOH species formed on the Au NPs can decompose the adsorbed TPA+ templates [30], thereby exposing more Ti active sites, particularly those far from the Au NPs. This means that the number of Ti active sites gradually increased during the induction period, which is the main reason for the gradual increase in the acetone formation rate during this period. Similar phenomena were observed in the direct gas-phase epoxidation of propene using H2 and O2 [8]. After the induction period, the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst exhibit a stable acetone formation rate of ca. 95 gAc·h−1·kgcat –1, with a propane conversion of approximately 3.0 %. Notably, no significant deactivation is observed within 100 h, indicating that the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst has excellent stability. Fig. 2 b illustrates the selectivities for acetone, isopropanol, and by-products over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B within 100 h. The initial selectivity for isopropanol is approximately 9.4 %, but then it drops sharply as the reaction proceeds. After the induction period, the selectivity for acetone and isopropanol become stable at ∼ 87.0 % and ∼ 5.7 %, respectively. Notably, the selectivity for the by-product propanal slowly increases from approximately 2.0 % to 3.0 % during the reaction, and the selectivity for the by-product CO2 shows a slight increase and then becomes stable. According to the previously reported work [1,2], both isopropanol and acetone are derived from the i-propoxy intermediate species generated from the reaction of propane with Ti-OOH reaction intermediates. During the induction period, the propane conversion, acetone formation rate, and acetone selectivity gradually increase, with acetone selectivity far exceeding that of other products. This suggests that the generation rate of i-propoxy intermediate species also gradually increases as the reaction proceeds. From a kinetic perspective, the increase in the concentration of i-propoxy intermediate species should enhance the formation rate of isopropanol. However, we observed that, unlike acetone, the formation rate of isopropanol remains relatively constant during the induction period (shown in Fig. S7 ). We then speculate that a portion of the isopropanol may be further converted into other products, that is, isopropanol may serve as a reaction intermediate. To verify this hypothesis, we analyzed the selectivity of isopropanol under different space velocities, and the results are shown in Fig. S8 . As show, the selectivity of isopropanol gradually increases with increasing space velocity, indicating that reducing the residence time of the feed gas in the catalyst bed is favorable for improving the selectivity of isopropanol. This result lends support to the above hypothesis. To further understand the kinetics of products' formation over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst, the effect of reaction temperature (180–230 °C) on the catalytic performance was investigated, and the results are shown in Fig. 3 . Evidently, both the C3H8 conversion and acetone formation rate (shown in Fig. 3 a) gradually increase with increasing reaction temperature, while the selectivity for acetone shows the opposite trend, which is consistent with previously reported work [2]. Moreover, as shown in Fig. 3 b, the selectivities for ethanol, acrolein, propanol, and CO2 increase with increasing reaction temperature, whereas the selectivity for isopropanol decreases. This indicates that the reaction producing isopropanol is less temperature-sensitive than those for by-products (such as propanol and CO2). Moreover, as discussed above, isopropanol acts as a reaction intermediate. Drawing from the results shown in Fig. 3 b, we can reasonably infer that elevated reaction temperatures may promote the formation of by-products, such as CO2, from isopropanol. Fig. 3 c shows Arrhenius plots for the formation rates of acetone, isopropanol, and by-products. The apparent activation energies of each product were obtained using the Arrhenius equation and shown in Fig. 3 d. The apparent activation energy for acetone lies between those of isopropanol and the by-products (such as ethanol and CO2), indicating that low reaction temperatures favor isopropanol, whereas high reaction temperatures favor the by-products. Therefore, strict control of reaction temperature is necessary to achieve high acetone selectivity [2]. As discussed above, isopropanol serves as a reaction intermediate because of its low selectivity at longer residence times (as illustrated in Fig. S8 ). Thus, it may be further converted into other products during the reaction. To gain deeper insight into the kinetic behavior of acetone and isopropanol formation over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst, the effects of reactant concentration on acetone formation rate and net isopropanol formation rate were also investigated (shown in Fig. 4 ). The acetone formation rate increases with increasing concentrations of C3H8, H2, and O2, indicating that all three reactants play a significant role in acetone formation (shown in Fig. 4 a–c). In contrast, the net isopropanol formation rate increases with increasing concentrations of C3H8 and H2 but decreases gradually with increasing concentration of O2 (shown in Fig. 4 d–f). According to previous studies, increasing the O2 concentration promotes the reaction between hydrogen and oxygen on Au NPs to generate HOOH species [31–33], which in turn boosts the formation of Ti-OOH reaction intermediates. This ultimately enhances the reaction of propane with Ti-OOH, thereby producing more isopropanol and acetone [1,2]. However, our results demonstrate that the net isopropanol formation rate decreases at higher O2 concentrations. The most likely explanation is that isopropanol is further converted to other products by O2, and hence, O2 makes a. greater contribution to the consumption of isopropanol than to its formation. This results in a lower net isopropanol formation rate under higher O2 concentrations. The reaction orders of C3H8, H2, and O2 for acetone formation over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst were measured by independently changing the concentration of each reactant (within 4–20 vol%), and the results are shown in Fig. 5 a–c. As shown, H2 and O2 have similar reaction orders whereas that of C3H8 is much higher. From this perspective, increasing the concentration of C3H8 will be more favorable for the improving the acetone formation rate. The reaction orders of C3H8, H2, and O2 for the sum of acetone and isopropanol formation over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst were also measured. Compared to the case for acetone formation alone, the reaction orders of C3H8 and H2 for the sum of acetone and isopropanol formation are very similar, while the reaction order of O2 for the sum of acetone and isopropanol formation is slightly lower (shown in Fig. 5 d–f). Moreover, the reaction orders of C3H8, H2, and O2 for forming all propane oxidation products over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst are close to those observed for the sum of acetone and isopropanol formation (shown in Fig. S9 ). 3.3 Analysis of adsorption sites for reactants and products To explore the pathways of acetone formation over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst, in-situ DRIFTS experiments were performed to identify the adsorption sites of propane, isopropanol, and acetone on the TS-1-B and S-1-B samples as well as the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts. The results are shown in Fig. 6 . Fig. 6 a displays the C3H8-DRIFTS results. All four catalysts exhibit a distinct negative peak at 3730 cm−1, which is due to the interaction between adsorbed C3H8 and surface hydroxyl groups [34]. The broad band observed at ∼ 3350 cm−1 can be attributed to O–H bonds in the perturbed Si–OH groups [35]. Notably, no characteristic peaks of C–H bonds are observed within 2800–3000 cm–1 in any of the C3H8-DRIFTS spectra [27] even under magnification. This may be due to the weak adsorption of propane molecules on the catalyst surfaces. The IPA-DRIFTS results are shown in Fig. 6 b. The absorption band at 3730 cm−1 is attributed to the interaction between isopropanol and surface hydroxyl groups [34], and the broad absorption band at 3350 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of O–H bonds in perturbed Si–OH groups [35]. Additionally, a weak absorption band located at 955 cm−1 is attributed to the out-of-plane bending vibration of O–H bond in IPA [36]. Notably, the peak intensities of the O–H bond in IPA show no significant differences among the four samples, indicating that the Ti sites and Au NPs have minimal influence on the adsorption of isopropanol. Fig. 6 c shows the results of Ac-DRIFTS. The negative absorption band at 3730 cm−1 is attributed to the interaction between adsorbed acetone and surface hydroxyl groups [34]. The broad absorption band at 3350 cm−1 is assigned to the stretching vibration of O–H in perturbed Si-OH groups [35], and the absorption band at 1710 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching vibration of C=O in acetone [37]. Notably, the area under the characteristic peak of acetone C=O bond (shown in Table S4 ) is similar between the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst and TS-1-B sample but lower for the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst and S-1-B sample, indicating that acetone molecules are primarily adsorbed on the Ti sites. To investigate the effect of acetone adsorption on Ti sites on the catalytic performance of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst, a gas mixture of 1.5 vol% acetone in N2 was co-fed into the reactor with varying flow rates. Details for this experiment are provided in the Supporting Information . As shown in Fig. 6 d, the acetone formation rate decreases with increasing acetone concentration at the inlet, yielding an apparent acetone reaction order of ca. –1.55 (fitting results shown in Fig. S10 ), clearly indicating that acetone significantly inhibits its own production. Additionally, following the method reported by Delgass et al. [33], the true apparent reaction orders of C3H8, O2, and H2 for the sum of acetone and isopropanol formation over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst were also corrected (shown in Table S5 ) by multiplying the orders observed in absence of acetone by a factor of ca. 2.55 (i.e., 1 minus the apparent order of acetone). The above results indicate that promoting acetone desorption is a key factor in improving the catalytic performance of Au-Ti bifunctional catalysts. Moreover, considering the inhibitory effect of acetone on its own formation, we also investigated the effect of acetone on the selectivity for isopropanol over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst under different space velocities, and the results are shown in Fig. S11 . As shown, when co-feeding 0.15 vol% acetone, the selectivity for isopropanol still increases with increasing space velocity, which is consistent with the results shown in Fig. S8 . Notably, the acetone formation rate calculated based on the mass of TS-1-B over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalyst is higher than that over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst (shown in Fig. 1 h). Unlike the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst, the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalyst was prepared by physically mixing 0.075 g of 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst and 0.075 g of S-1-B sample. When evaluating the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalyst and the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst under identical reaction conditions (i.e., the same reaction temperature, space velocity, and feed gas composition) and the same catalyst loading (i.e., 0.15 g), the propane conversion over the former catalyst (shown in Fig. S5 a) is lower than that over the latter catalyst (shown in Fig. 2 a). Additionally, given that the acetone selectivity does not differ significantly between the two catalysts (shown in Fig. 2 b and Fig. S5 c), we can reasonably speculate that the acetone concentration over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalyst is lower than that over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst. Consequently, compared to the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst, the lower acetone concentration on the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalyst results in weaker inhibition by acetone. This may explain why the acetone formation rate calculated based on the TS-1-B mass over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B catalyst is higher than that over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst. The effect of co-feeding isopropanol on acetone formation was investigated in a similar manner, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 e. Unlike the case of acetone, the acetone formation rate increases with the increasing concentration of co-fed isopropanol, thus yielding an apparent order of ca. 0.18 for isopropanol (fitting results shown in Fig. S10 ). Moreover, even when approximately 0.25 vol% isopropanol was co-fed at the inlet, the isopropanol concentration in the effluent is similar to the case without co-feeding isopropanol (shown in Fig. S12 ). This result indicates that most of the co-fed isopropanol was converted to acetone under reaction conditions. 3.4 Formation pathways of acetone Based on the analysis of adsorption sites for C3H8, acetone, and isopropanol, we further investigated the catalytic behaviors of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and Au/S-1-B catalysts under different reaction atmospheres, in order to gain a deeper understanding of the formation pathways of acetone. The reaction atmospheres used in the discrimination experiments are listed in Table 1. The results of the discrimination experiments show that no product is observed under any atmospheres over the S-1-B and TS-1-B samples, as expected (data not shown). Moreover, no product was observed over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B or 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst under QFC (containing C3H8 and N2), QFCH (containing C3H8, H2, and N2), or QFCO (containing C3H8, O2, and N2) atmospheres, indicating that H2 or O2 alone cannot oxidize the relatively inert propane. The energy barrier for activating C–H bonds in propane is relatively high, and hence it does not activate readily under mild reaction conditions [38]. In contrast, acetone, isopropanol, and by-products were observed when both H2 and O2 are present. Previous studies showed that the reaction between H2 and O2 on Au NPs can form HOOH species, which then diffuse to the Ti active sites to form the Ti-OOH reaction intermediates that selectively oxidize propane. Hence, the strongly oxidizing Ti-OOH reaction intermediates can effectively activate the C–H bonds in propane [1,2]. The selectivity for isopropanol over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst decreases with a decrease in space velocity (shown in Fig. S8 ), and the net isopropanol formation rate over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst decreases with increasing O2 concentration (shown in Fig. 4 f). Moreover, increasing the concentration of co-fed isopropanol also enhances the acetone formation rate (shown in Fig. 6 e). The above results indicate that isopropanol serve as a reaction intermediate, which can be converted to acetone under reaction conditions. To verify this hypothesis, a mixture of 1.5 vol% IPA in N2 was co-fed to the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 7 . The specific formation rates of different products are listed in Tables S6 and S7 . The conversion of isopropanol is relatively low under QFI (containing IPA and N2) and QFIH (containing IPA, H2, and N2) atmospheres over both catalysts (shown in Fig. 7 c and d). However, the conversion of isopropanol is nearly 100 % over the two catalysts under the QFIO atmosphere (containing IPA, O2, and N2) (shown in Fig. 7 c and d), and the main product is acetone. The conversion of isopropanol over both catalysts under QFIHO (containing IPA, O2, H2, and N2) atmosphere is also nearly 100 % (shown in Fig. 7 c and d). However, the formation rate (shown in Fig. 7 a and b) and selectivity of acetone (shown in Fig. 7 c and d) over these two catalysts are lower than those under QFIO atmosphere, and CO2 can be observed under the former atmosphere. This may be because of the deep oxidation of isopropanol and acetone. Fig. S13 shows the conversion of isopropanol (approximately 99.6 %) under a reaction atmosphere containing acetone, isopropanol, oxygen, H2O, and CO2, a composition that more closely resembles the real reaction conditions, over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst is very similar to that under a similar reaction atmosphere containing H2. Moreover, acetone formation rate in the latter atmosphere is slightly lower than that in the former reaction atmosphere without H2, and some CO2 is also formed in the latter reaction atmosphere. This may be due to the deep oxidation of isopropanol and acetone (as will be discussed below) in the atmosphere containing H2/O2. Therefore, based on the above results, we can reasonably assume that H2 has minimal influence on the conversion of co-fed isopropanol while O2 makes a more significant contribution. This is also consistent with previous reports showing that nanogold catalysts supported on multiple oxides can effectively catalyze the oxidation of isopropanol to acetone under an oxygen atmosphere with high conversion [39–41]. Moreover, it has been demonstrated that the interface between Au NPs and support is pivotal in activating O2 molecules [42–44], and that the interface between Au NPs and oxide is essential for the oxidation of isopropanol [39,41,45]. Therefore, we argue that isopropanol is more likely to be oxidized by O2 at the interface between Au NPs and TS-1-B or S-1-B particles. Some minor products are also generated over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts under QFI (containing IPA and N2) and QFIH (containing IPA, H2, and N2) atmospheres. Considering that the discrimination experiments were performed after the induction period, there should be some strongly adsorbed oxygen molecules as well as hydro-peroxy intermediate species at the interface between Au NPs and TS-1-B or S-1-B particles, which may oxidize isopropanol to acetone and ethanol. In addition, based on the catalytic performance of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst (shown in Fig. 7 a and c) under an atmosphere containing 10 vol% H2 and 10 vol% O2 (the same as in the reaction conditions) and 0.15 vol% isopropanol, as well as the stable acetone formation rate over this catalyst under the standard reaction conditions (i.e., 10 % H2/10 % O2/10 % C3H8/70 % N2, vol.%), the concentration of isopropanol formed from propane over this catalyst under standard reaction conditions is estimated to be approximately 0.32 vol%. Considering that the discrimination experiments with co-fed isopropanol (shown in Fig. 7) were conducted under a relatively low isopropanol concentration, we performed an additional experiment at a higher concentration of co-fed isopropanol (ca. 0.35 vol%) under a reaction atmosphere of 10 vol% H2/10 vol% O2/10 vol% C3H8/balance N2, in order to more clearly and closely mimic the real reaction conditions, and the results are shown in Fig. S14 . As shown, the conversion of co-fed isopropanol over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B under QFIHO atmosphere is also close to 100 % (∼98.5 %). This result also indicates that the isopropanol formed form propane over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst can be converted to acetone with high conversion under the reaction conditions. Our previous study found that the PO formation rate over the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst is close to that over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst [13]. This result indicates that the HOOH species generated on the Au NPs loaded on the Au/S-1-B catalyst can diffuse over a relatively long distance (ca. 120–450 nm) to the Ti active sites on the surface of TS-1-B particles to form PO [13], and the amount of decomposed HOOH species during the transfer process seems negligible. The above results also suggest that the Ti active sites far away from the Au sites can capture HOOH species to form Ti-OOH reaction intermediates, which subsequently facilitate the selective epoxidation of propylene to PO (detailed reaction steps in Scheme S1 ). On the Au NPs of Au/S-1-B catalyst, HOOH species are generated through the same mechanism (detailed reaction steps in Scheme S1 ) for both the direct epoxidation of propylene to PO and the selective oxidation of propane to acetone using H2 and O2 [2,13], which are conducted at the same reaction temperature and H2 and O2 concentrations (both at 10 vol%). Then, we assume that the HOOH species generated on the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst can also diffuse through the gas phase to the Ti active sites on TS-1-B, forming Ti-OOH reaction intermediates that selectively oxidize propane to acetone (detailed reaction steps in Scheme S1 ). Moreover, the above results also imply that the migration of the HOOH species between the surface of the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst and TS-1-B particles is not the primary reason for the lower acetone formation rate observed over the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst. Previous studies reported that the HOOH species generated on Au NPs react with Ti active sites to form Ti-OOH reaction intermediates, which then react with propane to form i-propoxy intermediate species. These i-propoxy intermediate species can be further oxidized to acetone by the HOOH species [1,2]. However, the results of our discrimination experiments here clearly demonstrate that isopropanol can also be converted to acetone under an oxygen atmosphere at the interface between Au NPs and TS-1-B or S-1-B particles, with a conversion approaching 100 %. This is consistent with the following two observations: (1) the acetone formation rate increases with increasing concentration of co-fed isopropanol (shown in Fig. 6 e) and (2) the net isopropanol formation rate decreases with increasing O2 concentration (show in Fig. 4 f). Based on the above results, we propose a new insight into the formation pathway of acetone in the selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2 over Au/TS-1-B catalyst (shown in Scheme 1 ). At the Au-Ti proximity sites, the HOOH species generated on the Au NPs diffuse to adjacent Ti active sites to form Ti-OOH reaction intermediates, which react with propane to form i-propoxy intermediate species. The i-propoxy intermediate species are then transformed into isopropanol [2]. Subsequently, isopropanol is further oxidized to acetone by oxygen at the Au-Ti interface. This suggests that only one HOOH molecule is required to form one acetone molecule at the Au-Ti proximity sites. Moreover, some HOOH species can diffuse to remote Ti active sites to form Ti-OOH reaction intermediates, which then react with propane to form i-propoxy intermediate species. Subsequently, the i-propoxy intermediate species are oxidized to acetone by HOOH species generated on the Au NPs, and a part of i-propoxy intermediate species can be further converted to isopropanol [1,2]. This indicates that two HOOH molecules are required to form one acetone molecule on remote Ti active sites. In other words, the Au-Ti proximity sites may be more efficient for acetone formation than the remote Ti active sites, because the latter requires more HOOH species to produce the same amount of acetone. This could also explain why the acetone formation rate over the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst (with less Au-Ti proximity sites) is lower than those over both the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalysts. The acetone co-feeding experiments (show in Fig. 6 d) indicate that the acetone formation rate decreases significantly when a higher concentration of acetone is co-fed. Moreover, the Ac-DRIFTS results (shown in Fig. 6 c) indicate that the acetone molecules are mainly adsorbed on the Ti sites. This should be the main reason for the lower acetone formation rate when a higher concentration of acetone is co-fed, because the Ti sites are responsible for the oxidation of propane. Notably, the apparent reaction order of acetone is ca. –1.55, while that of PO is ca. –0.6 [20], implying that the adsorption of acetone on Ti sites in the TS-1-B surface exhibits a stronger inhibitory effect than that of PO. This strong adsorption may also explain the lower acetone formation rate over the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst compared to that over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B + S-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalysts. Moreover, the diffusion and strong adsorption of acetone on the surface of Au-Ti bifunctional catalysts may also lead to fewer available remote Ti active sites for capturing HOOH species, which could explain why the remote Ti active sites contribute less significantly to acetone formation. According to Fig. 2, the conversion of propane and the formation rate and selectivity of acetone gradually increase during the induction period, whereas the selectivity for isopropanol gradually decreases. Moreover, the net isopropanol formation rate remains constant during the induction period (shown in Fig. S7 ). During this period, more Ti active sites (especially the remote ones) and Si sites were gradually exposed due to the decomposition of TPA+ templates on the external surface of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst. Wrasman et al. reported that the HOOH species generated on a Au-Pd/carbon catalyst could diffuse to the surfaces of TiO2 and SiO2 and then convert isopropanol to acetone [45], demonstrating that the HOOH species can also oxidize isopropanol adsorbed on the Ti and Si sites to acetone. Based on the above results, we infer that isopropanol formed on the remote Ti active sites (in smaller amounts than that formed at the Au-Ti proximity sites) and that adsorbed on the Si sites adjacent to the remote Ti active sites may be further oxidized to acetone by the HOOH species [45]. That is, although more Ti active sites (especially those far from the Au NPs) became available during the induction period to enhance the production of isopropanol, the additionally exposed Ti and Si sites also induced oxidation of most isopropanol formed on the remote Ti active sites by the HOOH species to form acetone. This is likely the main reason why the net isopropanol formation rate remains almost unchanged during the induction period. Specifically, during this period the increase in acetone formation rate is greater than that in net isopropanol formation rate, thus leading to a gradual decrease in isopropanol selectivity. Given that the acetone-DRIFTS results (shown in Fig. 6 c) demonstrate that acetone molecules can be adsorbed on Ti (primary adsorption sites) and Si sites, we analyzed the net formation rate of isopropanol when co-feeding different concentrations of acetone in order to verify the above hypothesis. As shown in Fig. S15 , the net formation rate of isopropanol increases with increasing acetone concentration. Based on this result and the fact that more acetone molecules are absorbed on the Ti and Si sites at higher concentrations of co-fed acetone, we can reasonably conclude that the HOOH species generated on the Au NPs diffuse to the Ti and Si sites and can also oxidize some of the isopropanol formed on the remote Ti active sites (in smaller amounts than that formed at the Au-Ti proximity sites) to acetone. This may be another pathway for acetone formation on the remote Ti active sites (shown in Scheme 1). 3.5 Formation pathways of CO2 and ethanal (1) Formation pathways of CO2 As shown in Fig. 7, when co-feeding the IPA/N2 mixture, the formation rate and selectivity of acetone under QFIHO (containing IPA, O2, H2, and N2) atmosphere are inferior to those under QFIO (containing IPA, O2, and N2) atmosphere over both the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts, while the formation rate and selectivity of CO2 show the opposite trend. A likely explanation is that the co-presence of H2 and O2 facilitates the conversion of acetone to CO2, potentially through O* radicals generated in the non-selective decomposition of HOOH or OOH* species [46], which in turn catalyze the deep oxidation of acetone [46,47]. To verify this hypothesis, we co-fed a gas mixture of 1.5 vol% acetone in N2 at 3.5 mL/min over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts, and the results are shown in Fig. 8 . The formation rates of different products are shown in Tables S8 and S9 . It is evident that CO2 is only formed under QFAHO (containing acetone, O2, H2, and N2) atmosphere over both catalysts (show in Fig. 8 a and b), and CO2 is also the main product in these cases. Considering that the reaction of H2 and O2 on Au NPs yields HOOH and OOH* species [32,46], which can undergo non-selective decomposition to form H2O and O* radicals [46], we can assume that the O* radical oxidizes acetone to CO2 [46,47]. Notably, the conversion of acetone and the formation rate and selectivity of CO2 under QFAHO atmosphere over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst (shown in Fig. 8 a and c) are superior to those over the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst (shown in Fig. 8 b and d). This suggests that Ti sites play an important role in the deep oxidation of acetone. Considering that the adsorption of acetone on the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst is stronger than that on the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst (shown in Fig. 6 d), we can conclude that acetone adsorbed on the Ti active sites near the Au NPs is deeply oxidized by the O* radical formed on the Au NPs to generate CO2. Moreover, it is possible that Ti-OOH species can oxidize acetone to form CO2. The above results led us to conclude that the Au-Ti proximity sites and remote Ti active sites contribute more significantly to the deep oxidation of acetone than the Au sites on the surface of Au NPs. Notably, the CO2 formation rate over the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst under QFIHO (containing IPA, O2, H2, and N2) atmosphere (shown in Fig. 7) is higher than that under QFAHO (containing acetone, O2, H2, and N2) atmosphere (shown in Fig. 8). It is reasonable to assume that some of the CO2 is also formed by deep oxidation of isopropanol at the interface between the Au NPs and S-1-B particles. Fig. 3 b shows that the selectivity to CO2 increases gradually with rising reaction temperature, while the selectivity to isopropanol shows the opposite trend. Based on these results, we speculate that higher temperatures may promote the deep oxidation of isopropanol, thereby resulting in high selectivity to CO2. In addition, no CO2 was observed over the two catalysts when propane and O2 were co-fed (data not shown). The above results also suggest that the increase in the acetone formation rate and the conversion of isopropanol during the induction period promote the deep oxidation of acetone and isopropanol, thereby improving the selectivity for CO2. Furthermore, the decomposition of TPA+ templates during the induction period is another reason for the increased selectivity for CO2 [48]. (2) Formation pathways of ethanol Notably, as shown in Fig. 7, minor amounts of ethanol are formed over both the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalysts under QFIO atmosphere, indicating that O2 can oxidize isopropanol to ethanol at the interface between Au NPs and TS-1-B or S-1-B particles. However, no characteristic peaks of CO2 were observed in the chromatograms for the two catalysts under QFIO atmosphere, possibly because the small amount of CO2 produced fell below the GC detection limit. No ethanol is formed over both the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B and 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst when co-feeding acetone and O2 (show in Fig. 8 a and b). However, as shown in Fig. 8 a and b, ethanal is formed over both the two catalysts when co-feeding H2, O2, and acetone. Notably, the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst exhibits higher selectivity for ethanol than the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst under QFAHO (containing IPA, O2, H2, and N2) atmosphere. Moreover, the amount of ethanol formed over the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst under QFIHO (containing IPA, O2, H2, and N2) atmosphere is higher than that under QFAHO (containing IPA, O2, H2, and N2) atmosphere. These results indicate that the deep oxidation of acetone and isopropanol by O* generated from the non-selective decomposition of HOOH or OOH* species can also yield ethanol on Au NPs [46]. Compared to the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B catalyst, HOOH or OOH* species generated on the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst can be promptly captured by adjacent Ti sites to form Ti-OOH reaction intermediates, resulting in a lower concentration of these species on the Au NPs (i.e., a lower concentration of O*), thus leading to a lower selectivity for ethanol under QFAHO and QFIHO atmospheres. Based on the above results, we conclude that ethanal primarily originates from the deep oxidation of isopropanol and acetone by O* radicals on the Au NPs [46], as well as the oxidation of isopropanol at the interface between Au NPs and TS-1-B or S-1-B particles. Notably, the formation rate of CO2 is significantly higher than that of ethanol, and one reason for this may be the further oxidation of ethanol to CO2. 4 Conclusions This study offers new information about the formation pathways of acetone in the selective oxidation of propane with H2 and O2 over Au/TS-1-B catalyst, by integrating kinetic analysis, in-situ DRIFTS measurements, and carefully designed discrimination experiments. The selectivity for isopropanol gradually decreased during the induction period, whereas the selectivities for acetone and CO2 showed the opposite trend. Moreover, increasing the reaction temperature led to an inferior selectivity for isopropanol, which is different from the case of by-products such as ethanol and CO2. In addition, increasing the O2 concentration led to a decrease in net isopropanol formation rate, whereas the acetone formation rate exhibited the opposite trend. The acetone formation rate over the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst was much higher than that over the 0.10 wt% Au/S-1-B + TS-1-B tandem catalyst, demonstrating that the Au-Ti proximity sites contribute more significantly to acetone formation than the remote Ti sites. In-situ DRIFTS results demonstrated that acetone molecules are mainly adsorbed on the Ti sites. Co-feeding acetone into the reactor can significantly decrease the activity of the 0.10 wt% Au/TS-1-B catalyst (apparent reaction order of acetone = –1.55). The results of co-feeding isopropanol showed that isopropanol could be further oxidized to acetone. The strong adsorption of acetone on the Ti sites, along with the higher requirement for HOOH species to form acetone on the remote Ti active sites, is responsible for the inferior activity of these Ti active sites. Based on the above findings, we propose that, for the Au/TS-1-B catalysts, acetone mainly originates from the oxidation of isopropanol by O2 at the Au-Ti interface. Meanwhile, a small amount of acetone is also generated on the remote Ti active sites, potentially resulting from the oxidation of IPA formed on these Ti active sites (in a smaller amount than the isopropanol formed at the Au-Ti proximity sites) by HOOH species. Moreover, isopropanol and acetone can undergo deep oxidization to form CO2 on the Au NPs, Au-Ti proximity sites, and remote Ti active sites. Finally, ethanal is mainly formed by deep oxidization of isopropanol and acetone on the Au NPs. The insights reported in this work may show considerable influence on the rational design of highly efficient Au/TS-1-B catalyst for the reaction. coredata.dc:description: Understanding the reaction mechanism is crucial for the rational design of highly efficient catalysts. Herein, we report new insights into the formation pathway of acetone in the selective oxidation of propane using H2 and O2 catalyzed by uncalcined titanium silicalite-1 (i.e., TS-1-B) immobilized Au nanoparticles, based on kinetic analysis, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy, and well-designed discrimination experiments. Increasing the concentrations of propane and H2 favored the formation of both acetone and isopropanol. However, a higher O2 concentration decreased the net rate of isopropanol formation while increasing that of acetone formation. The acetone formation rate increased with the concentration of co-fed isopropanol. Moreover, the results of co-feeding isopropanol with different reactants demonstrated that isopropanol can be converted to acetone by oxygen at the interface between Au nanoparticles and supports with a conversion near 100%. Moreover, we also found that the Au-Ti proximity sites contribute more significantly to the formation of acetone compared to the remote Ti sites in the Au/TS-1-B catalyst. Based on the above results, we propose that acetone primarily originates from the oxidation of isopropanol by oxygen at the Au-Ti interface of Au-Ti bifunctional catalysts, which differs from the claim in previous reports that acetone is formed through the oxidation of isopropoxy intermediate species by hydro-peroxy species on the Ti sites. Moreover, isopropanol and acetone undergo deep oxidation to form CO2 and ethanol as by-products.
